fields.name: Southeast
fields.description: South East England is renowned for its beautiful gardens and miles of stunning coastline. Rich in cultural attractions, the region is easily accessible from London, and is also home to miles of gentle rolling countryside, two National Parks, and some of Britain’s driest weather! Step back in time in medieval villages and quintessential coastal towns, explore history in armour filled museums and palatial architectural gems. This exquisite region has so much to offer and is home to a charming little town called London...Counties include Berkshire, Buckinghamshire, East Sussex, Hampshire, the Isle of Wight, Kent, Oxfordshire, Surrey and West Sussex.

fields.name: Southwest
fields.description: Over the coasts and valleys in southwest England lie the mysterious mists of Camelot: the craggy peaks of Cornwall, the fertile farmlands of Somerset, the drizzly charming Dorset villages, the grassy, gusty Devon moors. The so-called 'West Country' is the legendary region of Arthurian knights and cuckolded kings, Moorish pirates and Mayflower pilgrims, Stone Age sacrifices and solstice awakenings. It also has more sunshine and tends to be warmer than the rest of England, but that may be a myth too. One thing there's no myth surrounding in these parts in though, is the real country pub. Counties include: Bristol, Cornwall, Dorset, Devon, Gloucestershire, Somerset, and Wiltshire, the Isles of Scilly.

fields.name: The Midlands
fields.description: The Midlands, formally known as The Heart of England, is a region rich in history and unspoiled countryside. Discover the region that gave birth to Shakespeare, the Industrial Revolution and the greatest hoard of Anglo-Saxon gold and silver metalwork ever found. From hiking in the beautiful Peak District to crossing the world's first Iron Bridge, there's no shortage of things to do- or pubs to visit. In the Midlands you'll be simply spoiled for choice when it comes to finding a cosy pub to have a pint and while away the hours. Counties include: Derbyshire, Herefordshire, Leicestershire, Lincolnshire, Northamptonshire, Nottinghamshire, Rutland, Shropshire, Staffordshire, Warwickshire, Worcestershire.

fields.name: The East
fields.description: Eastern England's greatest treasure is the glorious variety of its landscapes. From the quintessentially English county of Suffolk to the seaside county of Norkfolk, down to the wild countryside of Essex and the lush, marshy fenland, cathedral towns, and medieval markets of Cambridgeshire- this is the East. Travel through England’s history with some of the country’s best preserved Roman remains, Normal motte-and-bailey castles, Tudor keeps, and you guessed it- pubs! Counties include: Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, Essex, Hertfordshire, Norfolk and Suffolk.

fields.name: Northeast
fields.description: From the Scottish borders to the counties of Yorkshire, North East England is a region often overlooked by tourists and natives from other parts of Great Britain. To those that know the North East, there is a wealth of natural beauty surprisingly unspoiled by the large number of visitors the area attracts. It's a region of contrast. From the wild beauty of the Northumberland National Park to the modern life of Newcastle, the new, the old and the disused all reside in stark relief. The real beauty of North East England is its secret. So few know what this area really has to offer- including an array of off the beaten path pubs in this wild setting. Counties include: Northumberland, County Durham, Tyne and Wear, Yorkshire.

fields.name: Northwest
fields.description: Counties include: of Cheshire, Cumbria, Greater Manchester, Lancashire and Merseyside.

fields.name: The Five Alls
fields.description: | FILKINS | GLOUCESTERSHIRE | Tucked in the quaint Cotswolds village of Filkins, The Five Alls ofers an exciting blend of traditional English fare with an Italian twist. The honeystone inn covered in climbing plants exudes country appeal – this is a theme that continues inside, with logs piled high, charming fagstone foors and a cosy freplace to gather around. Seasonal cocktails, The Five Alls' house ale and an extensive wine list ofer a tipple for every taste, while a menu infuenced by the town's artisan producers promises a foodie treat, combined with the head chef's Italian connections. Upstairs, there are four en-suite rooms above the inn and a further fve bespoke bedrooms reached from the picturesque garden.
fields.address: The Five Alls, Filkins, Lechlade GL7 3JQ

fields.name: The Pandora Inn
fields.description: | FALMOUTH | CORNWALL| Few pubs can claim to serve fsh fresh from the boat, but Falmouth’s 13th-century Pandora Inn does. But that’s not the only thing that makes this inn special. Home to a cosy, character bar and restaurant, you can hunker down on a blustery day and enjoy food by the fre. When the sun shines, the pub’s foating pontoon becomes the star of the show with meals served on the water. The experience is relaxed, with cofee and cake kicking of proceedings in the morning, followed by a series of locally sourced daily specials and traditional coastal dishes. St Austell’s Brewery ales, Cornish Orchards’ cider and Tarquin’s local gin stock the bar with local drinks.
fields.address: The Pandora Inn, Restronguet Creek, Mylor Bridge, Falmouth TR11 5ST

fields.name: The Gloucester Old Spot
fields.description: | CHELTENHAM | GLOUCESTERSHIRE | A testament to their commitment to serve the local village and neighbouring towns well, The Gloucester Old Spot is among the rare breed of pubs to serve food seven days a week. The bar is cosy and rustic and the restaurant a real treat. Enjoy seasonal and locally sourced food from comfy country furniture, while the fickering log burner and atmospheric lighting give the exposed brick walls a sense of theatre. Local ciders and hand-pulled ales keep the bar well supported, with drinks changing frequently. The historic towns of Tewkesbury and Cheltenham are also conveniently located nearby.
fields.address: Tewkesbury Rd, Piffs Elm, Cheltenham GL51 9SY

fields.name: The Gurnard's Head
fields.description: | ST. IVES | CORNWALL | A landmark pub almost at the edge of England, the Gurnard’s Head is your last stop for a pint and an open free before the Atlantic Ocean. Between St Just and Zennor, this is genuine Cornwall. Wild, mysterious and beautiful, the Gurnard’s Head is an inn that transports you back to when travel was that little bit slower. With Excellent dining room and comfortable beds, the Gurnard's Head is both a welcome stop-ff and a destination within itself. The food is simple, fresh, local wherever possible and of exceptional quality. As such, this pub regulalry features in national pub guides and has a loyal following near and far.
fields.address: Nr Zennor, Saint Ives, Penzance TR26 3DE, United Kingdom

fields.name: The Tinner's Arms
fields.description: | ZENNOR | CORNWALL | The Tinners Arms dates back to the 13th century and has been at the heart of village life in Zennor for over 700 years. With low ceilings, stone floors and seaward terrace it exudes charm and character from every nook and cranny just as you would expect. It is a pub for all seasons; an open fire, stone floors and low ceilings make for a cosy bar even when outside a storm is blowing of the Atlantic. In the summer the beer garden becomes a Mecca for those walking the nearby south west coastal path toward St Ives. Wear hiking boots - or take a beautiful, short drive around the area. Today's visitors can count on a warm welcome, real ale, fresh fish from the Atlantic, and Cornish cheeses. Topped off with a good variety of spirits, the Tinners is will worth a visit.
fields.address: Zennor, St Ives TR26 3BY, United Kingdom

fields.name: The Village Pub
fields.description: | BARNSLEY | GLOUCESTERSHIRE | At The Village Pub you can trundle around in your wellies then settle down to a more luxurious side of pub life. Tuck into quail scotch eggs, Butts Farm beef in ale pie, huge fish cakes and home-made ice cream. Almost every ingredient on the menu includes the producer's name, and dishes change daily according to what is in season. There are flagstone floors, exposed stone walls, polished wood, and animal heads on the walls. Dried wheatsheafs decorate the bar and the decor adheres to the compulsory Cotswolds palette of moss greens and muted greys, both downstairs and up in the six bedrooms on offer. Staff are jolly and helpful and have maps on hand for long walks and picnics. This village pub is everything one could hope for.
fields.address: The Village Pub, Barnsley, Gloucestershire, England

fields.name: The Lamb At Hindon
fields.description: | HINDON | WILTSHIRE | A 12th century coaching inn in the idyllic setting  of postcard ready village Hindon. With it’s flagstone flooring, old oak beams and roaring fireplaces, it’s the perfect place for a bite to eat to break up a long journey through the West Country, a cycle stop to refuel and soak up the sunshine on our terrace garden, or a weekend getaway to relax and recharge. Intimate English village Inn full of charm and history - an institution for 800 years. Renovated, elegant rooms are cosy and plush. Guests are welcomed by roaring fires, hearty meals, and beautiful surroundings. A country escape or a stopover en route further West.
fields.address: High Street, Hindon, Salisbury, Wiltshire, SP3 6DP

fields.name: The Old Swan
fields.description: | MINSTER LOVELL | OXFORDSHIRE | The Old Swan & Minster Mill is an exceptional, quintessential country inn and boutique hotel in the heart of Oxfordshire. Beamed celings, roaring log fires, and rugged flagstone floors feature next to luxuriously classic interiors. The outdoor terrace and picturesque gardens are a treat during the summer months. Expect fresh local, flavoursome ingredients and hearty housemade dishes; from a pie and pint by the fireside in the colder months, or a salad on the terracein the summer. The menu is seasonal and the foos is simple. The Garden Spa offers hotel guests a tranquil and indulgent haven in the heart of this pub's beautiful grounds.
fields.address: Old Swan, Minster Lovell, Oxfordshire, Cotswolds, OX29 0RN

fields.name: Nobody Inn
fields.description: | DODDISCOMBSLEIGH | DEVON | Brave the twisty-turny lanes to get to Doddiscombsleigh's only pub, the Nobody Inn. The 16th-century building is everything you would expect from a country pub: imposing fireplaces, oak beams, snuggly corners and then some. The bar is extremely well stocked, selling more than 300 types of whisky, the most expensive being the 1938 Glenlivet at £97 a tot, as well as an eponymous beer brewed in Branscombe especially for the inn. Food varies from delicious pub grub at lunch to game and fish in the evening, all with the emphasis on keeping producer-to-plate miles as low as possible. If you have even a smidgen of space left at the end of supper, indulge in the cheese board, a choice of six or nine of the 15 local cheeses, including Sharpham brie, Ticklemore goats' cheese and Devon Blue. There are also five bedrooms upstairs if you want to extend your country escape for a little longer.
fields.address: Nobody Inn, Doddiscombsleigh, near Exeter, Devon EX6 7PS

fields.name: The Mermaid Inn
fields.description: | RYE | SUSSEX | The Mermaid Inn is situated in the beautiful medieval town of Rye. Originally a fishing town and then part of Normandy, this ancient Cinque Port town is steeped in history. Found on a fantastic cobbled street, the Inn has maintained the essence of true English charm for over 800 years and still has original features including a cellar dating back to 1156. The whole inn boasts huge freplaces, sloping ceilings and creaking floorboards, stories of smugglers, secret passageways and a huge list of famous visitors. Ghosts are rumoured to roam the pub and thirty-one bedrooms. Request a ‘ghost-free’ room when booking (if you prefer).
fields.address: The Mermaid Inn, Mermaid Street, Rye TN31 7EY

fields.name: The Three Chimneys Freehouse
fields.description: | BIDDENDEN | KENT | The Three Chimneys is an award-winning, independent country pub in Biddenden. Exceptional scenery surrounds the building, which dates back to 1420, and being steeped in local history is everything one would expect from a traditional Kentish pub. Visitors are greeted with dark oak beams, roaring fires, and five separate dining areas strewn with aged hops for which the county of Kent has long been known. Craig Smith, who packed in his City job to take over the pub in 1999 serves Welsh Rarebit, Haddock Fishcakes and deep fried brie. There are five luxury bedrooms available but oddly boasts only two chimneys. An ideal refreshment stop-of if you are visiting nearby Sissinghurst Castle or Scotney Castle. Dogs are welcome.
fields.address: Three Chimneys, Hareplain Road, Biddenden TN27 8LW

fields.name: The Old Neptune
fields.description: | WHITSTABLE | KENT | The Old Neptune, known locally as Neppy, is a cosy, seaside boozer and the subject of many a photo of Whitstable. The pub is located directly on the seafront which is an idyllic spot to spend an hour or two on a sunny afternoon. Its close position to the centre of the town makes it walkable from all of the popular eateries and boutiques. They have a good selection of local ales and not so local lagers, as well as standard pub grub. The pebble beach on which it sits is family friendly and ofers a relaxed environment. They host live music events and are also dog-friendly.
fields.address: The Old Neptune, Marine Terrace, Whitstable CT5 1EJ

fields.name: The Hind's Head
fields.description: | BRAY | BERKSHIRE | Established as a hunting lodge and coaching inn in the 1400s, The Hind’s Head in Bray is a traditional pub by Heston Blumenthal, infused with the innovative and creative ethos he applies to food and for which he is renowned. The menu refects the establishment’s British heritage. With an interior of soft blues, stained glass and oxblood leather banquettes set against original beams, dark wood fooring and inglenook freplaces, this Michelin-starred restaurant ofers astounding culinary genius in the relaxed setting of a traditional pub environment in one of the most idyllic riverside village locations of Bray.
fields.address: High Street, Bray, Berkshire SL6 2AB

fields.name: The Mash Inn
fields.description: | RADNAGE | BUCKINGHAMSHIRE | The Mash Inn is a boutique inn in Buckinghamshire with a prestigious reputation. Described as a restaurant with rooms, the open kitchen cooks the best seasonal fair on a bespoke wood-fired grill and many ingredients are sourced from Inn's own kitchen garden. The founder Nick Mash believes in authentic country dining experiences and in supporting local craftsmen and producers. Foraging for ingredients, pulling vegetables out of the ground and having them on your plate within a couple of hours only reinforces this unique yet traditional approach to country dining. The vibe is both rustic an d luxurious and offer beautiful countryside views.
fields.address: Horseshoe Road, Bennett End, Radnage, Buckinghamshire HP14 4EB

fields.name: Gomshall Mill
fields.description: | GUILDFORD | SURREY | Situated on the River tillingbourne, Gomshall Mill is a beautiful timber-framed mill dating from Medieval times. Ancient floorboards, oak beam, and open fires create an authentic and traditional pub environment. British classes fill the menu along woth some intentional fusion options. The mill existed at the time of the hostoric Domesday book, a historical manuscript record acting as a census for much of England and parts of Wales completed in 1086 by order of King William the Conqueror. The existing building from the 1600's still contains some of the original milling machinery that gives this pub it's name.
fields.address: Charlton Road, Charlton PO18 0HU

fields.name: The Fox Goes Free
fields.description: | CHARLTON | SUSSEX | The Fox Goes Free is an alluring country pub in the quaint village of Charlton, West Sussex. The pub is 400 years old & full of oak beams, fint walls and open freplaces. In warmer days, a pleasant afternoon can be spent in their large country garden overlooking the South Downs and nearby Goodwood Estate. This listed building is surrounded by stunning, countryside walks. Wherever possible, their cuisine is locally sourced, home-made and includes favourites such as calamari and chorizo, fsh pie and rib eye steak.
fields.address: Charlton Road, Charlton PO18 0HU

fields.name: Fisherman's Cottage
fields.description: ISLE OF WIGHT | SHANKLIN | If you fancy food by the sea, the Isle of White’s Fisherman’s Cottage will tick all your boxes with its seafront location and thatched pub charm. You’ll count boats and breakers for neighbours as you enjoy a pint at Shanklin’s oldest pub, built in 1817. It’s located close to Shanklin Chine, a breath-taking gorge that is an island must-see. The water also inspires the menu, with seasonal fsh, Bembridge crab and lobster and an epic fsh and chips taking pride of place alongside traditional meat dishes. Catch the sun on the patio or hunker down in the dining room – this pub is a gem whatever the weather.
fields.address: Shanklin Esplanade, Shanklin, Isle of Whight PO37 6BN

fields.name: Sir Charles Napier
fields.description: | OXON | OXFORDSHIRE | The beautiful, 18th-century fint embellished Sir Charles Napier Inn sits in a beautiful spot in the Chilterns amongst scenic English gardens. With two roaring wood fres crackling away, the food here is exceptional and the views are mesmerising. The Inn has earned its reputable status over the decades it has been established. The Sunday roasts here are legendary and ingredients are based on their seasonal availability. Inside, the atmosphere is cosy and leans towards formal in the dining area, which is carpeted and resembles a country house dining room. People travel from far and wide to experience Sir Charles Napier Inn and have done for years.
fields.address: Spriggs Alley, Chinnor, Oxon OX39 4BX

fields.name: The Chequers Inn
fields.description: | WOOLSTHORPE | HEREFORDSHIRE | Quintessentially English, with the cricket pitch to prove it, The  Chequers Inn at Woolsthorpe offers award-winning cuisine, a well-stocked bar and unspoilt views to keep diners, drinkers and dog walkers happy for hours.  The Vale of Belvoir is where you’ll find this little gem. And while the drive may take you further afield, if it is an experience you’re after, you’ll definitely get one here.  Open fires and plenty of character features make you feel at home in this 17th century pub. the whiskey lovers who that will think they have died and gone to heaven. With a selection of more than 50 single malts adorn the bar so you can sip for as long as your desire in front of the crackling fire, it's the whiskey lovers who that will think they have died and gone to heaven.
fields.address: The Chequers Inn, Main Street, Woolsthorpe By Belvoir, near Grantham, NG32 1LU

fields.name: The Martins Arms
fields.description: | COLSTON BASSETT | NOTTINGHAMSHIRE | Situated in the idyllic village of Colston Bassett, in the Vale of Belvoir, The Martins Arms is a traditional English pub with landscaped gardens overlooked by the village church. Dark reds, dark wood, open fire, candlelight and traditional pictures of Victorian life decorate the walls creating the interior of this popular pub. The menu os traditional with old English dishes like duck, hunstman pie and pork ribeye.The pub holds numerous awards including a reccomendation from Michelin.The Martins Arms encapsulates all that is best in an English pub and is a welcome retreat at any time of the year.
fields.address: School Ln, Colston Bassett, Nottingham NG12 3FD, United Kingdom

fields.name: The Riverside at Aymestrey
fields.description: | LEOMINSTER | HEREFORDSHIRE  | The Riverside at Aymestrey - Authentic and atmospheric, the 16th century black and white building is surrounded by the natural beauty of the River Lugg valley. Situated deep in the heart of Herefordshire countryside just on the southern edge of the Mortimer Forest, yet still close to Ludlow and Hereford, this pub is considered among the very best in all of England. This is one you won't want to pass by.
fields.address: The Riverside Inn, Leominster HR6 9ST, Herefordshire, United Kingdom

fields.name: The West Arms
fields.description: | LLANARMON DYFFRYN-CEIRIOG | WREXHAM | Technically just over the Welsh border from Shropshire, this one is just too splendid to leave out. The picturesque village of Llanarmon Dyffryn Ceiriog, in the remote Ceiriog valley, is home to this inn in a farmhouse dating back to 1570. It’s a community hub but also does unusual gourmet food (fish with Menai Strait mussels and sauteed sea vegetables, perhaps). This bit of north Wales has bags of charm and interesting spots include dramatic Pistyll Rhaeadr waterfall, the idiosyncratic town of Llangollen and the 13th-century Chirk Castle, with a vast parkland that’s glorious in autumn, and Erddig House, with Christmas events such as walks and breakfasts with Santa from the end of November. You’re close to Snowdonia, too.
fields.address: The West Arms, Llanarmon Dyffryn-Ceiriog, Wrexham, LL20 7LD, Wales

fields.name: The Fuzzy Duck
fields.description: | ARMSCOTE | WARWICKSHIRE | With a double aspect fireplace, this contemporary Cotswold pub is the perfect spot to enjoy a lazy weekend lunch or romantic supper with the ability to roll upstairs to one of their luxurious bedrooms, each named after a species of duck which can be found on the lakes of Armscote Manor. Working with the best local suppliers to create delicious seasonal menus, thw cuisine takes it's lead from the beautiful surrounding Cotwolds and the abundant ingredientsthat can be found there. The pub itself feels thoughfully stylish with every detail considered. This is a Cotswold gem.
fields.address: TIlmington Rd, Armscote, Stratford-upon-Avon CV37 8DD

fields.name: Royal Oak
fields.description: | CARDINGTON | SHROPSHIRE | Not too from the walks on Caer Caradoc – a steep, windy four-hour schlep up a Bronze-age hill fort The Royal Oak can be found. On a warm day relax outside on a roadside terrace in front of the establishment and afterwards, take a stroll along the stream at the back. It remains a very ‘old Shropshire’ boozer – patronage ranges from farmers in Tattersall check settling by the fire with still-wet sheepdogs to visitors from the city. Satisfy a craving for bygone rural traditions is with a pint of unfiltered ale at the Royal Oak, located in a fifteenth-century house in Cardington, Shropshire. Don't leave without ordering the pork-and-apple fidget pie, made with gammon cooked in spiced cider, with a golden puff-pastry top.
fields.address: The Royal Oak, Cardington, North Church Stretton, Shropshire, SY6 7JZ

fields.name: The Bell Inn
fields.description: | CARDINGTON | SHROPSHIRE | Not too from the walks on Caer Caradoc – a steep, windy four-hour schlep up a Bronze-age hill fort The Royal Oak can be found. On a warm day relax outside on a roadside terrace in front of the establishment and afterwards, take a stroll along the stream at the back. It remains a very ‘old Shropshire’ boozer – patronage ranges from farmers in Tattersall check settling by the fire with still-wet sheepdogs to visitors from the city. Satisfy a craving for bygone rural traditions is with a pint of unfiltered ale at the Royal Oak, located in a fifteenth-century house in Cardington, Shropshire. Don't leave without ordering the pork-and-apple fidget pie, made with gammon cooked in spiced cider, with a golden puff-pastry top.
fields.address: The Royal Oak, Cardington, North Church Stretton, Shropshire, SY6 7JZ

fields.name: Duncombe Arms
fields.description: | CARDINGTON | SHROPSHIRE | Not too from the walks on Caer Caradoc – a steep, windy four-hour schlep up a Bronze-age hill fort The Royal Oak can be found. On a warm day relax outside on a roadside terrace in front of the establishment and afterwards, take a stroll along the stream at the back. It remains a very ‘old Shropshire’ boozer – patronage ranges from farmers in Tattersall check settling by the fire with still-wet sheepdogs to visitors from the city. Satisfy a craving for bygone rural traditions is with a pint of unfiltered ale at the Royal Oak, located in a fifteenth-century house in Cardington, Shropshire. Don't leave without ordering the pork-and-apple fidget pie, made with gammon cooked in spiced cider, with a golden puff-pastry top.
fields.address: The Royal Oak, Cardington, North Church Stretton, Shropshire, SY6 7JZ

fields.experience: Cozy and I want to live there.
